The origin of the claim: The earliest version of the claim appeared in a Facebook post on March 10, 2021, published by an account called Jimoh Sule. This information was obtained from social media monitoring tool CrowdTangle.
Circulation of the claim: The claim was reshared on Facebook by a page called Buhari Reporters, which has nearly 250,000 followers. It was also shared on Twitter by a user who describes himself as a "Core Buharist" and was further shared by Buhari's social media aide, Lauretta Onochie. Other individuals, including Joe Igbokwe and Jack Obinyan, also shared the images and false claims.
Verification through image search: A Google reverse image search of one of the photos led to an online article from September 27, 2020. The article revealed that the image was first published online on August 7, 2017, by Israel Ibeleme, a media aide to Nigeria's Minister for Transportation, Rotimi Amaechi. The image was taken during Amaechi's inspection of Agbor Station, which has now been renamed after Goodluck Jonathan and is part of the Itakpe-Ajaokuta-Warri rail line.
Contextual information: The claim was made in the context of a debate between supporters of President Muhammadu Buhari and his predecessor, Goodluck Jonathan, over who gets credit for recent rail projects in Nigeria. The Nigerian government has been working on diversifying its economy away from the oil sector and has undertaken various rail projects, including the Port Harcourt-Maiduguri narrow gauge railway, which was recently launched with a $3.2 billion project.
